title: Alpha Epsilon Delta Texas Zeta Chapter
descriptionSnippet: The Texas Zeta Chapter of AED has its roots in the TCU Premed/PreHealth Honor Society which was formed in 1975 with Dr. Manfred Reinecke as its faculty advisor. The society expanded to the point that, in 1978, a committee was formed to petition for aff...
fullDescription: The Texas Zeta Chapter of AED has its roots in the TCU Premed/PreHealth Honor Society which was formed in 1975 with Dr. Manfred Reinecke as its faculty advisor. The society expanded to the point that, in 1978, a committee was formed to petition for affiliation with the national organization AED. AED approved the petition, and on April 20, 1979, the Texas Zeta chapter of AED was established at TCU with the initiation of 31 active members, three active alumni, and five honorary members. Dr. Reinecke served as the faculty advisor until 1991 and was followed by Dr. Phil Hartman. Dr. Matt Chumchal succeeded Dr. Hartman in 2012 and served as the interim faculty advisor and officially taking the position in 2013. Dr. Chumchal currently resides as the chair of the TCU's Health Professions Committee and Dr. Reinecke and Dr. Hartman have also served as chairs. In addition, both Dr. Reinecke and Dr. Hartman have served as Regional Directors to the national organization. It may be of interest to know that there has been tremendous stability to TCU's Pre Health Professions Program. This is evidenced by the long tenure of each head of the program, noted as follows: Will Winton 1918-1950 Willis G. Hewatt 1950-1972 Manfred Reinecke 1972-1991 Phil Hartman 1992-2012 Matt Chumchal 2013-present -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The objectives of AED are to: * Encourage and recognize excellence in prehealth scholarship * Stimulate an appreciation for prehealth education * Promote cooperation and contacts between health professions students and premedical students and educators in developing an adequate program of prehealth education * Bind together similarly interested students * Use its knowledge for the benefit of health organizations, charities, and the community.

fullDescription: College Insider is a service led organization focused on mentoring the teens in the Fort Worth Community and surrounding areas. We partner with The Communities In Schools organization in Fort Worth to bring local high school and junior high students to TCU's campus for a day. The high school students are partnered with a TCU Student mentors, tour the campus and get to hear their Mentor's (TCU Student) story on their experience here on campus. The majority of the high school students have been identified by their school as "at risk" and may have no interest in attending a college or university. The Organization aims to ignite an interest in college for these teens and educate them on the opportunities that are available for them in the post-secondary education field. We aim to grow the partnerships in the community in the following years and have more schools in the community become a part of the partnership.

title: Delta Sigma Pi
descriptionSnippet: Delta Sigma Pi is a professional fraternity organized to foster the study of business in universities; to encourage scholarship, social activity and the association of students for their mutual advancement by research and practice; to promote closer af...
fullDescription: Delta Sigma Pi is a professional fraternity organized to foster the study of business in universities; to encourage scholarship, social activity and the association of students for their mutual advancement by research and practice; to promote closer affiliation between the commercial world and students of commerce, and to further a higher standard of commercial ethics and culture and the civic and commercial welfare of the community. Delta Sigma Pi was founded in 1907 at New York University: School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance by Harold Valentine Jacobs, Alexander Frank Makay, Alfred Moysello and Henry Albert Tienken. Today, coast to coast, there are 270 chapters and over 230,000 members that support the goals and ideals of the Fraternity. The Delta Upsilon Chapter at Texas Christian University was founded in 1959.

title: Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc
descriptionSnippet: The Iota Eta Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. was charted on the campus of Texas Christian University on April 22, 1972 by seven illustrious Delta Women. The Iota Eta chapter serves the TCU community through various empowerment sessions, pub...
fullDescription: The Iota Eta Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. was charted on the campus of Texas Christian University on April 22, 1972 by seven illustrious Delta Women. T he Iota Eta chapter serves the TCU community through various empowerment sessions, public service opportunities, and socials. Delta Sigma Theta (ΔΣΘ) is a non-profit Greek-lettered sorority of college-educated women who perform public service and place emphasis on the African American community. Delta Sigma Theta was founded on January 13, 1913, at Howard University by twenty-two illustrious women and now, over 100 years later, Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Inc. has become the largest African-American Greek-lettered sorority in the world. Membership in Delta Sigma Theta is open to any woman who meets the membership requirements, regardless of race, nationality, or religion. Women may join through undergraduate chapters at a college or university, or after acquiring a college degree through a graduate chapter. The Grand Chapter has a membership of more than 350,000 predominantly African-American, college-educated women, and educated Caucasian, Asian, Native American, Hispanic, and African women. The sorority currently has 950-plus alumnae and collegiate chapters located in the United States, England, Japan (Tokyo and Okinawa), Germany, Bermuda, the Bahamas, Seoul, Saint Thomas and Saint Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands; Haiti and Jamaica.[1] Delta Sigma Theta is a member of multiple organizations, including the National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC) — an organization of nine international Greek-letter sororities and fraternities - as well as the NAACP, and the National Council of Negro Women (NCNW). The current national president is Cynthia M. A. Butler-McIntyre.

title: Disciples on Campus
descriptionSnippet: Disciples on Campus is a welcoming community of Christians exploring their faith through worship, spiritual growth, mission, service, Bible studies & discussion groups. Here you are welcome. Here you are wanted.
fullDescription: Disciples on Campus is a welcoming community of Christians exploring their faith through worship, spiritual growth, mission, service, Bible studies & discussion groups. We welcome all students to be part of our DOC family, just the way you are! Rev. Lea McCracken is our wonderful campus minister that serves alongside our Leadership Team to guide DOC on its journey. We have over 275 Disciple students on campus coming from all over the United States and many other parts of the world. TCU DOC (Disciples on Campus) is the on campus community of Disciples students and friends! We create community, support one another and build bridges. We worship together, serve the community and engage in study and dialogue among ourselves and with others. We hope to bring the best of what it means to be Disciples to the TCU campus, our communities, and God's creation. Mission: Disciples on Campus is a student organization at Texas Christian University formed as a community that provides a presence for the Disciples of Christ at Texas Christian University, so that Disciple students have an avenue to continue their spiritual growth in college. Disciples on Campus offers various vehicles to achieve this through worship services, mission and service projects, weekly meals and devotionals, retreats, and many other student initiated ministries. Vision: Disciples on Campus will be one of the prominent and respected religious voices that contribute to spiritual growth and development at Texas Christian University where all students are welcomed, affirmed, and challenged to grow into Christians who seek to improve the communities in which they live and the world.

fullDescription: This organization promotes the linguistic and cultural exploration of the more than 50 countries around the world where French is spoken, including the United States. Through campus and community service activities, ENSEMBLE EN FRANÇAIS connects to students, staff, and faculty on campus as well as to key groups in the community, primarily kids, and offers meaningful programs to increase awareness of the culture and language of France and other Francophone countries but also to demonstrate the value of learning French in today's global society. In addition, ENSEMBLE engages in fund raising efforts for DOCTORS WITHOUT BORDERS. New students with a genuine interest in the French speaking world and/or who are taking French at TCU or have learned it elsewhere can join the organization and get involved in its operation. An election of new officers is conducted at the end of every spring.

title: Entrepreneurship Club
descriptionSnippet: The Entrepreneurship Club at TCU focuses on education and encouragement of students to succeed as entrepreneurs. The overall purpose of the Entrepreneurship Club is to foster interest in the field of entrepreneurship, develop entrepreneurial stategies,...
fullDescription: The Entrepreneurship Club at TCU focuses on education and encouragement of students to succeed as entrepreneurs. The overall purpose of the Entrepreneurship Club is to foster interest in the field of entrepreneurship, develop entrepreneurial stategies, improve methods and techniques of business management, learn how to create an entrepreneurial venture, encourage practices in pursuit of entrepreneurial opportunities, utilize entrepreneurial skills through community outreach efforts, and develop lasting relationships among students, faculty and the business community.

title: Environmental Club
descriptionSnippet: As the only environmental organization on campus, our MISSION is to promote environmental awareness through outreach and education within the TCU community in a NON-PARTISAN way. In other words, we want to encourage fellow students, faculty, and staff ...
fullDescription: As the only environmental organization on campus, our MISSION is to promote environmental awareness through outreach and education to both the TCU community and the general public in a NON-PARTISAN way. We wish to encourage fellow students, faculty, staff, and the members of the public to become environmentally friendly by providing the necessary opportunities and then showing them how. We take action! Our organization participates in cleaning the Trinity River, partnering with other like-minded organizations to bring more impact to various individuals, spending time with nature through nature hikes, and trying our best to make TCU and the public greener every day!

title: Food Recovery Network
descriptionSnippet: Food Recovery Network is a national student-led organization with the mission of fighting waste and feeding people. Members of the organization have the opportunity to make a difference in their community by signing up for weekly deliveries.
fullDescription: Food Recovery Network at TCU is a food recovery program to help end hunger in the Tarrant County area. The organization partners with local shelters, rescue missions, and non-profits to help collect and retrieve leftover food from the university and deliver it to these establishments. The TCU-FRN will commit to educating the public on food waste, hunger, and available resources to help combat hunger. By providing meals to those affected by hunger and promoting awareness of the environmental benefits of diverting food waste, TCU-FRN directly reflects the university’s mission and values, specifically pertaining to being responsible citizens in the global community.

title: French Language House
descriptionSnippet: La Maison Française, The TCU French Language House, is part of Mabee Hall, the language immersion residence hall at Texas Christian University, a wing of the Tom Brown-Pete Wright Residence. The French Language House programs are specifically designed ...
fullDescription: La Maison Française, The TCU French Language House, is part of Mabee Hall, the language immersion residence hall at Texas Christian University, a wing of the Tom Brown-Pete Wright Residence. The French Language House programs are specifically designed for French minors and majors as well as students who are fulfilling their language requirement and who want opportunities to practice the French language outside the classroom in a home environment. The French Language House programs include movie nights, French and Francophone cultural events, diners, trips to near and far Francophone destinations, study hours, conversation tables, and much more. Students who are interested in living in the French Language House and engage in the many events are invited to apply for the Fall 2019-Spring 2020 Please contact Dr. Marie Schein to receive the complete application.

title: FroggieFriends
descriptionSnippet: FroggieFriends was created as an opportunity to make a significant impact in not only the lives of TCU students, but also the greater Fort Worth community as a whole. We have created a program where TCU students go to Paschal High School once per week ...
fullDescription: FroggieFriends was created as an opportunity to make a significant impact in not only the lives of TCU students, but also the greater Fort Worth community as a whole. We have created a program where TCU students go to Paschal High School once a week and participate in a mentorship program with the students who have special needs. We have played adaptive games such as bowling with water bottles and a foam ball, addition bingo, trash can basketball, volleyball, and many other games. Our goal is to provide a friend and mentor that the students at Paschal can look up to and become great friends with. The students at Paschal look forward to us coming every week and the impact that we leave simply by putting in one hour a week is so meaningful. To celebrate the end of the year we like to do fun, different things. One year we went to a TCU baseball game, another year we had a scavenger hunt around Paschal football field, and this past year we had a pizza and ice cream sundae party!

title: Lambda Theta Alpha Latin Sorority, Incorporated
descriptionSnippet: The year 1975 saw the birth of what started as a vision - an idea of an organization, a sisterhood that would cater to the needs of Latinas and the universal woman. Thanks to the tremendous strides made by our seventeen founding mothers, this dream was...
fullDescription: Lambda Theta Alpha Latin Sorority, Incorporated is the First and Largest Latin Sorority in the nation. The sorority was founded in December of 1975 by 17 lovely Founding Mothers at Kean University in Union, New Jersey. The original purpose of Lambda Theta Alpha was to establish a support system for Latina women pursuing higher education. Its focus was to actively integrate women into the social, political and community service arena in order to make their voices as loud as the majority. "Latin by Tradition, not by Definition" has been adopted by the organization to continue to guide women of all backgrounds to become Universal Women along the principles of Unity, Love, and Respect.

title: Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity Inc. - Beta Pi Chapter
descriptionSnippet: Since our inception on December 1, 1975, Lambda Theta Phi has grown coast to coast as the first and largest Latin fraternity in the United States. Founded at Kean University, in Union, New Jersey, our 14 Founding Fathers congregated with the vision to ...
fullDescription: Since our inception on December 1, 1975, Lambda Theta Phi has grown coast to coast as the first and largest Latin fraternity in the United States. Founded at Kean University, in Union, New Jersey, our 14 Founding Fathers congregated with the vision to unite all Latinos regardless of nationality. Today, Lambda prides itself on its multi-cultural brotherhood of gentlemen from different creeds, nationalities, and religious beliefs. Our brothers, nationwide, stay true to our mottos “En la union, esta la fuerza”/”In unity, there is strength” and “Chivalry Above Self,” and set the precedent of what it means to be fraternal men, gentlemen, and role models in the community.

fullDescription: MBACC was created as a professional organization for MBA students to pursue occupational goals related to the Consulting industry. We are unique in two distinct ways. First, we are a new club with huge growth potential. As a member--and especially as a club officer--it is easy to make an impact on future generations of Neeley MBAs through implementing your ideas within MBACC. Second, we are a club that spans across all concentrations. Whether you are interested in Corporate Strategy, IT, Private Equity, Marketing or other industries, Consulting may be the career for you! Furthermore, the events that we sponsor are beneficial whether you plan to become a Consultant or a Financial Analyst or a Brand Manager post-grad. The faculty sponsor for our club is the Director of Experiential Learning, in charge of the esteemed Neeley and Associates Consulting program along with Dr. Larry Peters. Both work professionally as Consultants and have endless contacts in the industry. Our key goals for 2015 are: to educate MBA candidates on the possibility of pursuing a Consulting career and to connect students with influential community leaders to help further the career goals of MBA candidates at the the Neeley School of Business.

fullDescription: The National Society of Collegiate Scholars (NSCS) is an honor society inviting high-achieving college students. Members must rank in the top 20 percent of their class to receive an invitation. NSCS is proud to offer more money for undergraduate scholarships than any other honor society nationwide. But more than that, NSCS is a growth opportunity, leadership training ground, and resource. Students who join meet people on campus and at other schools they might not have otherwise – people who become friends, long-term supporters, and future colleagues. Students who join get the tools and encouragement they need to take part in transforming the on-campus and community-wide issues that mean the most to them. Students who join find they have a wealth of resources to help with their futures: NSCS-only scholarships; leadership training; internships, and careers; job leads and resources; and travel opportunities.

fullDescription: The Neeley Fellows is an undergraduate program of the Neeley School of Business at TCU whose purpose is to educate and develop students of extraordinary potential with both curricular and co-curricular experiential learning opportunities so these individuals can affect change in the global business community. The program challenges top students to stretch beyond their already competitive undergraduate coursework in business and provides opportunities to interact with top faculty and business executives both inside and outside of the classroom. The Neeley Fellows Program recognizes excellence and rewards it through exciting out-of-class growth opportunities for students. The program begins in the sophomore year. title: Omega Delta Phi Fraternity Inc.
descriptionSnippet: The purpose of this Brotherhood, a Service/Social fraternity dedicated to the needs and concerns of the community, is and shall be to promote and maintain the traditional values of Unity, Honesty, Integrity, and Leadership. This Brotherhood was founded...
fullDescription: The purpose of this Brotherhood, a Service/Social fraternity dedicated to the needs and concerns of the community, is and shall be to promote and maintain the traditional values of Unity, Honesty, Integrity, and Leadership. This Brotherhood was founded in order to provide, to ANY man, a diverse fraternal experience which coincides with a higher education. Since founding in 1987, Omega Delta Phi has been an organization perpetually dedicated to the idea of constant growth and improvement. We must work to form an organization which not only challenges the traditional perception of fraternities, but also deals with the issues of culture and race in a completely new perspective. Omega Delta Phi is a multicultural service/social fraternity that aims at graduating its members while giving back to the community. The Fraternity has established itself on 50+ campuses and is predominantly centered in Texas and the Southwest. However, the Fraternity has been experiencing tremendous growth in the Midwest the last 10 years. Although founded primarily by Latinos, the Fraternity has traditionally always been open to men of different backgrounds, as demonstrated through its “One culture, any race” philosophy.

title: Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc.
descriptionSnippet: On Friday evening, November 17, 1911, three Howard University undergraduate students, with the assistance of their faculty adviser, gave birth to the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity. This event occurred in the office of biology Professor Ernest E. Just, the f...
fullDescription: On Friday evening, November 17, 1911, three Howard University undergraduate students, with the assistance of their faculty adviser, gave birth to the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity. This event occurred in the office of biology Professor Ernest E. Just, the faculty adviser, in the Science Hall (now known as Thirkield Hall). The three liberal arts students were Edgar A. Love, Oscar J. Cooper and Frank Coleman. From the initials of the Greek phrase meaning "friendship is essential to the soul," the name Omega Psi Phi was derived. The phrase was selected as the motto. Manhood, scholarship, perseverance and uplift were adopted as cardinal principles. A decision was made regarding the design for the pin and emblem, and thus ended the first meeting of the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity.

title: Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia
descriptionSnippet: The Object of this Fraternity shall be for the development of the best and truest fraternal spirit; the mutual welfare and brotherhood of musical students; the advancement of music in America and a loyalty to the Alma Mater.Sinfonia was born on Oct..
fullDescription: The Object of this Fraternity shall be for the development of the best and truest fraternal spirit; the mutual welfare and brotherhood of musical students; the advancement of music in America and a loyalty to the Alma Mater. Sinfonia was born on October 6, 1898 at the New England Conservatory in Boston, when a group of thirteen young men under the guidance of Ossian Everett Mills met “to consider the social life of the young men students of that institution” and “to devise ways and means by which it might be improved.” Mills, bursar of the Conservatory, sought to create an Order in which men with a shared love of music could develop the virtues of manhood in themselves and in their fellows. Sinfonia became a national fraternity on October 6, 1900, with the admission of a group of men at the Broad Street Conservatory in Philadelphia. Since that time Sinfonia has grown into the largest music fraternity in the world, with more than 150,000 initiates, and chapters on over 200 college and university campuses across the nation. For over a century, Sinfonians in nearly every field of study and professional endeavor have transformed the face of music in America. Today, the Brotherhood represents a diverse group of individuals spanning the nation, who continue the proud tradition of advancing the Fraternity’s Object. Sinfonia is a Brotherhood of men bound together for mutual helpfulness. Its purpose is not only to bring men together as friends, but also to provide a network of brothers with whom men can commune and renew their zeal — a support network that helps the individual to meet the challenges that face him in his daily life. By teaching men who are united as brothers to live their lives according to the noble virtues set forth in the Fraternity’s Initiation Ritual, Sinfonia builds better, stronger, broader individuals who are able to live in sympathy and in harmony with their Fraternity brothers and their fellow man. The Initiation Ritual of Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia, which will mark the transition into full membership, is one of the most meaningful and beautiful of the Greek tradition. The dedication to the advancement of universal Truths and brotherly association exemplified in the Ritual are the foundation of individual fraternal friendship, chapter unity, and national solidarity in the promotion of Sinfonia’s dual mission: the making of men and the uplift of mankind. Sinfonians share a love of music that unites them as brothers with a common interest. The Fraternity teaches men to develop themselves and their art, not for the sake of art itself, but as a means of enriching the lives of others. Through a multitude of chapter, provincial, and national events, Sinfonia offers unlimited opportunities for performance, community music outreach, and other activities designed to develop a true appreciation for the power of music to uplift the soul. Sinfonia’s collegiate chapters participate in a broad range of activities emphasizing brotherhood, service, and performance in music. Chapters take music into the community by singing at hospitals and homes for the elderly; sponsor concerts of American music, jazz and choral festivals, all-campus sings and Broadway-style reviews; provide a large variety of performing ensembles ranging from big bands to barbershop quartets; commission new works; bring prominent performers and clinicians to their campuses; and take part in a variety of other social and musical activities. The possibilities for participation in musical activities are limited only by the boundaries of imagination, desire, and commitment. Sinfonia provides many exciting opportunities for the development of social and leadership skills in an atmosphere of brotherhood and mutual support. Leadership roles may be assumed from nearly the first day an individual is pledged to become an active member of the Fraternity. Beyond the chapter, annual province workshops and national events allow members to become more involved and to develop meaningful friendships with other musical students across the nation.

title: Pi Kappa Phi Fraternity
descriptionSnippet: The Eta Chi Chapter of Pi Kappa Phi was first conceived during the summer of 1996. Four men on the New Student Orientation Staff had developed a unique friendship while working together throughout the summer. First, they had developed a special bond – ...
fullDescription: The Eta Chi Chapter of Pi Kappa Phi was first conceived during the summer of 1996. Four men on the New Student Orientation Staff had developed a unique friendship while working together throughout the summer. First, they had developed a special bond – a brotherhood – that they did not want to end with the summer. Second, many incoming freshmen with strong leadership backgrounds in high school were being drawn into fraternities that did not nurture their potential. In their opinion, fraternities at TCU fell into one category: drinking clubs. They felt it was a shame that many men like themselves who wanted a fraternal experience that was more than a “drinking club,” did not have a viable option within the existing Greek system. They also believed the TCU fraternities had strayed away from the original purpose of fraternity – scholarship, leadership, service, and social experiences. They took the necessary steps for fraternity expansion at TCU and in March 1998 the first members were officially initiated into Pi Kappa Phi Fraternity at TCU. Today, we keep that vision alive by maintaining the same values that the chapter was founded upon

title: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc.
descriptionSnippet: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. (ΣΓΡ) was founded on November 12, 1922, at Butler University in Indianapolis, Indiana by seven young educators. It was incorporated within the state of Indiana in December 1922 and became a national collegiate sorority on...
fullDescription: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. (ΣΓΡ) was founded on November 12, 1922, at Butler University in Indianapolis, Indiana by seven young educators. It was incorporated within the state of Indiana in December 1922 and became a national collegiate sorority on December 30, 1929, when a charter was granted to the Alpha chapter. The sorority is a non-profit whose aim is to enhance the quality of life within the community. Public service, leadership development and the education of youth are the hallmark of the organization's programs and activities. Founded in the midst of segregation, Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. is the only sorority of the four historically African-American sororities which comprise the National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC) established at a predominantly white campus. Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. has over 100,000 members with more than 500 undergraduate and alumnae chapters throughout the United States, Bermuda, The Bahamas, Canada, Africa and Korea. Sigma Gamma Rho also supports two affiliates: the Rhoers, a group of young women, and the Philos, women who are friends of the sorority.

fullDescription: South Asian Inter-Cultural Association (SAICA) is a cultural organization that aims to emphasize diversity at TCU. Our organization is open to all students who are interested in exploring the cultures represented in South Asia. Last year, our members hailed from several countries including India, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, USA, Mexico, Nepal, Bangladesh, Ecuador and Vietnam. We promote and share South Asian cultures within the TCU community by indulging in South Asian music, food, ethnic dances, festivals and sports like cricket. SAICA also provides a great opportunity to meet culturally diverse people within an South Asian enriched environment through its events, specially The Mela Carnival and Experience South Asia, that it organizes during the year.

descriptionSnippet: Since 1914, the Student Government Association has worked to fulfill its mission: to represent the collective voice of the student body while encompassing the spirit of the TCU community through service, programming and legislation.SGA is comprised of ...
fullDescription: Since 1914, the Student Government Association has worked to fulfill its mission: to represent the collective voice of the student body while encompassing the spirit of the TCU community through service, programming and legislation. SGA is comprised of four branches: 1) Legislative The House of Student Representatives gives the student body a voice by authoring and voting on legislation designed to improve life at TCU. 2) Executive The Executive Branch is the main body responsible for leading Student Government and communicating with the student body. This branch is composed of the Student Body Officers, Cabinet, and Frog Aides freshman leadership program. 3) Programming theCrew and theEnd fund, plan, and execute a variety of activities and events on-campus, such as Frogs First, Family Weekend, Homecoming, Holidays at TCU, concerts, movie nights and much more. 4) Judicial The Judicial Board listens to and decides on matters relating to the violation of Student Government’s governing documents.

The goal of the TCU Garden Club is to provide students with the opportunity to gain experience and knowledge on how to grow a garden and to educate individuals on activities that are sustainable for our planet. Additionally, students will be given the opportunity to connect with other students in a wholesome environment and find opportunities to serve the school and the community by donating all produce to a charitable organization. What We Do The objectives of the programs, seminars, and opportunities provided by the TCU Leadership Center are to help students: * Identify and describe different leadership concepts, models, and skills. * Describe and evaluate their personal leadership style. * Demonstrate application of knowledge, skills, and talents related to leadership in diverse settings. * Describe strategies to apply their personal leadership style to engage and make positive change in their communities. If you are interested, contact Logan Lawson (Logan.lawson17@tcu.edu) or Will Dalgarn (will.dalgarn@tcu.edu).

Through collegiate tournaments, it is the goal of the organization to demonstrate quality skill level, and amazing sportsmanship.

fullDescription: Members of TCU Students for Life work to peacefully save lives threatened by induced abortion, euthanasia and destruction of human embryos for research. In furtherance of these goals, members seek to promote respect for life at Texas Christian University and in the surrounding community, to educate on life issues through campus outreach and activism, to help those in need so that life is a promising choice and to work with others who share common goals.

fullDescription: TCU Talking Frogs is a relatively new club to the TCU Community. At Talking Frogs we help you improve your leadership skills, learn improvisation and teach you the skills to becoming a confident communicator. The mission of the organization is to provide a supportive and positive learning experience in which members are empowered to develop communication and leadership skills, resulting in greater self-confidence and personal growth. Speaking in front of a large audience might seem intimidating, whether you're just learning to speak English or want get better at presentations . We are a friendly, fun and nurturing club that fosters personal growth for leadership and public speaking through practice. We offer a supportive and encouraging environment, we will help you learn how to successfully formulate and express your ideas and command a room full of people.

fullDescription: Dance Marathon is a year long fundraiser to raise money for Cook Children's Medical Center. The main focus is on the kids that endure countless trials through their sicknesses, and to help raise money to make them better.

descriptionSnippet: theCrew is a behind-the-scenes group that implements events for students at TCU, making the live music, movies, wild animals, video games, art and other chaotic events go off up to three times a day! Every Monday, our massive group meets up at 8:00pm o...

Every Monday, our massive group meets up at 8:00pm on the 1st Floor of the BLUU behind the Info Desk. You’ll choose a team based on your availability and get paired up with a dynamic duo of team leaders. In your team, you’ll brainstorm some wild events and start planning out the details that will bring your ideas to life and brighten someone’s day. Every week, we’re all here to relax, unwind, and have a good time while coming up with the next big thing for TCU.

title: Ultimate Frisbee Club
descriptionSnippet: Ultimate Frisbee is a limited-contact team sport played with a 175 gram flying disc. The object of the game is to score points by passing the disc to a player in the opposing end zone, similar to an end zone in American football or rugby. Players may o...
fullDescription: Ultimate Frisbee is a limited-contact team sport played with a 175 gram flying disc. The object of the game is to score points by passing the disc to a player in the opposing end zone, similar to an end zone in American football or rugby. Players may only move one foot while holding the disc. However, there is so much more to ultimate than just the game. There are the friendships and bonds you make with the players on your team as well as players on other teams from all around the country. We have a team dinners, hangouts, late nights and so much more with one another. Its a great way to be a part of something at TCU and meet new people on and off campus!

title: United Against Inequities in Disease
descriptionSnippet: The UAID mission is “to empower students and communities to eliminate health inequities locally."
fullDescription: Health inequities are unjust and preventable differences in health between groups of people. United Against Inequities in Disease (UAID) is a national organization that empowers students and communities to fight injustice and eliminate health inequities. The UAID Chapter at Texas Christian University is dedicated to identifying and researching health inequities within nearby communities and implementing a year-long project to decrease negative health outcomes. In addition to this project we plan to host speaker series, hold film screenings, and have panel discussions around current public health issues.

fullDescription: This organization will be achieving UNICEF’s mission, by raising awareness and fundraising throughout the TCU campus. It will be about taking ACTION, we will be hosting meetings, events, and volunteering off campus. The organization also helps TCU students broaden their perspective, enhance their leadership skills, and give them a chance to fight for children on an international scale.

title: Up 'Til Dawn
descriptionSnippet: Up 'Til Dawn is a student led organization that raises money for St. Jude Children's Research Hospital and brings awareness of childhood cancer and other diseases to campus. St. Jude is on the forefront of cancer research and admits all children--regardl
fullDescription: Up 'Til Dawn is a student-led organization that raises money for St. Jude Children's Research Hospital and brings awareness of childhood cancer and other diseases to campus. St. Jude is on the forefront of cancer research and admits all children--regardless of their ability to pay. St. Jude was founded on the belief that that every child, no matter their financial status, should be able to receive treatment. For this reason, no family every receives a bill from St. Jude and they freely share all of their cancer research with the medical community. At the end of Up 'til Dawn's fundraising period, the organization holds a celebration competition event in which teams stay "Up 'til Dawn" to fight cancer!

VISA Corps members serve as peer advisors to assist prospective study abroad students; host the Study Abroad Fair and other major events to generate interest in study abroad; present to TCU classes and groups to inspire and encourage other TCU students to pursue learning abroad; and serve as ambassadors for study abroad.

fullDescription: Vietnamese Student Association (VSA) is a cultural student organization that strives to strengthen student unity, represent Vietnamese students’ voice, and enhance diversity at TCU. We are passionate about promoting Vietnamese culture at TCU through fun and exciting events such as Lunar New Year Celebration, Mid-Autumn Festival, and Vietnamese Traditional Game Day. VSA is open to all TCU students who are interested in exploring Vietnamese unique culture, beauty, and traditions. VSA also serves as a caring and inclusive community where members develop strong bonds, share experiences, and support each other with personal and career development.

fullDescription: Welcome! We are a religious community of Christian students at TCU who are seeking to grow in faith and serve our community of students at TCU. The Wesley Foundation is historically based in the Methodist tradition and named after John Wesley, the founder of Methodism. We welcome students of all faiths to worship and grow in faith with us. We worship, pray, study the Word, serve our city, eat, have fun, and do life together. Come hang out at our building, grab a soda, and throw your hammock up on the pergola. We hope to see you around!

fullDescription: Word of Truth Ministries is TCU’s very own Gospel Choir. We are named ministries because we are more than just a gospel choir, we are a ministry. We minister to others not only through song but in our everyday lives. In addition, we minister through community service. Word of Truth has been in existence for over 25 years and continues to grow each year. Our possibilities are endless with the direction and guidance from our Lord, Jesus Christ. We are composed of current TCU students who are working towards an undergraduate or graduate degree. Throughout the year Word of Truth holds several concerts, socials, and participates in community service.

fullDescription: TCU Young Life is a place for old and new friends of Young Life to meet, get involved and grow in their relationship with Jesus Christ. We have traditional Young Life "club" and also offer campaigners (small groups).

title: Zeta Tau Alpha
descriptionSnippet: The Gamma Psi Chapter of Zeta Tau Alpha at Texas Christian University
